newsitem.title: JAPAN: News Corp denies report on size of JSkyB outlay.
newsitem.headline: News Corp denies report on size of JSkyB outlay.

text.p: A spokeswoman for News Corp Ltd in Japan on Wednesday denied a newspaper report which quoted chairman Rupert Murdoch as saying he was considering investing up to 100 billion yen ($917 million) in JSkyB.
JSkyB is a planned multi-channel digital satellite broadcasting service in Japan.
"He did not say how much News Corp would invest in the project," the spokeswoman said, without elaborating.
The Japanese daily Asahi Shimbun reported on Tuesday that Murdoch told the newspaper's senior executives he was considering investing up to 100 billion yen in the venture.
The spokeswoman said no one from News Corp at the meeting mentioned the possible amount of investment.
News Corp said earlier this year it would form a joint venture Japan's Softbank Corp to offer the JSkyB service.

Softbank said when it announced the establishment of the venture in June that the joint company would buy out Obunsha Media for 41.75 billion yen ($383 million). Obunsha has an equity stake of 21.4 percent in major television network Asahi National Broadcasting Co (TV Asahi).
The Asahi Shimbun group is the largest shareholder in TV Asahi, holding 38.3 percent stake in the broadcaster.
Murdoch and Softbank president Masayoshi Son held talks with a top official of Japan's Posts and Telecommunications Ministry on Tuesday about the planned satellite broadcasting service.
They told the head of the ministry's Broadcasting Bureau they would like to start a service as soon as possible, a ministry official told reporters.
The official said the firms would be granted a licence for a TV service using the JCSAT-3 satellite this autumn. They would be able to start services as early as next year, he said. ($1=109 yen)
